noun.description: Combustion or burning, in which substances combine chemically with oxygen from the air and typically give out bright light, heat, and smoke.
examples: his house was destroyed by fire

noun.description: A burning sensation in the body.
examples: the whiskey lit a fire in the back of his throat

noun.description: The shooting of projectiles from weapons, especially bullets from guns.

verb.description: Discharge a gun or other weapon in order to explosively propel (a bullet or projectile)
examples: he fired a shot at the retreating prisoners
they fired off a few rounds
having to fire men who've been with me for years

verb.description: Supply (a furnace, engine, boiler, or power station) with fuel.
Stimulate or excite (the imagination or an emotion)
Bake or dry (pottery, bricks, etc.) in a kiln.

phrases: the defeat has left him breathing fire
He has worked with him as a player and a pundit and doesn't see much difference from the gum-chewing manager who used to breathe fire from the dugout.
You can bet your last dollar if this happened in my school district I would be raising hell so fast and so loud I would be breathing fire.
Well, to go around with a father who breathes fire every time you go out to someone's house…
As a strong police posse stood around watching, district fan club members gathered, forming an angry group and breathing fire at the critical references to their hero.
origin: Old English fȳr (noun), fȳrian supply with material for a fire, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch vuur and German Feuer.
